positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing myself getting caught up in self-criticism again. I can see how my actions didn't meet others' expectations, and that's okay. Rather than dwelling on it, I'll take a moment to acknowledge the mistake and consider what I can learn from it. Letting go of regret and focusing on moving forward will help me grow and improve.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the ways you've disappointed people?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to mess up like that? What was wrong with me today? How could I be so careless and thoughtless, putting others in an uncomfortable position?
reference_transformed_example: Breathe in for 4 counts, breathe out for 6. Thinking about this more won't solve anything.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been feeling overwhelmed by all the challenges lately, but I've learned to acknowledge those feelings instead of letting them consume me. When I start to feel like giving up, I remind myself that it's normal to hit roadblocks and that every struggle is an opportunity to learn and grow. Instead of getting stuck in hopelessness, I take a step back, focus on my strengths, and re-energize by setting small achievable goals for myself. It's not about avoiding problems altogether, but about finding the right mindset and support system to tackle them head-on.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How tired does it make you to think about fighting your problems anymore?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why even try? It's all just a waste of energy anyway... Every problem feels like this never-ending mountain to climb, and the thought of putting one foot in front of the other is exhausting me.
reference_transformed_example: I remember when everything started feeling like a mountain to climb; it was when I got that disappointing feedback at work. It was just one bad review, but my mind went into overdrive. Middle of the experience was when I felt overwhelmed by all the negative self-talk and doubts creeping in. And then, there was the end - me just giving up on even trying. Looking back, I see how emotions like frustration and anxiety were swirling around every step. I didn't know how to make sense of it all at first, but now I can see patterns emerge.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm still trying to make sense of yesterday's events, but I've come to accept that not every detail needs to be shared. It's okay if people don't know the intricacies of my morning commute or the coworker's tedious small talk – it doesn't define the core message I want to convey. Today's reflective journaling helped me prioritize what truly matters and align those thoughts with my values. By focusing on the meaningful connections, like Sarah's job update, I'm more confident in sharing my experience without getting bogged down in unnecessary details.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: How much background information do you feel you need to provide to be understood?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to explain what happened yesterday, but my brain is just flooding with every single detail – like the stupid traffic jam on the way there, and the weird conversation I had with that coworker who always talks too much... why do I need to remember all of this? It's not even relevant to the point I'm trying to make... But what if someone doesn't understand me without knowing these tiny little details? Maybe they'll think I'm being vague or dishonest, and then we'll get into an argument...
reference_transformed_example:
I'm trying to explain what happened yesterday, but my brain is just flooding with every single detail – like the stupid traffic jam on the way there, and the weird conversation I had with that coworker who always talks too much... why do I need to remember all of this? It's not even relevant to the point I'm trying to make... But what if someone doesn't understand me without knowing these tiny little details? Maybe they'll think I'm being vague or dishonest, and then we'll get into an argument...

I was stuck on that thought for a bit, but as I started writing down my daily meaning tracking tonight, something shifted. I realized that focusing on the irrelevant details wasn't going to help me get my point across. Today's meaningful moment was actually the conversation with Sarah about her new job – it connected to my value of supporting others' growth. When I rate my sense of life meaning today, I'd say it's a 6 out of 10 – not ideal, but I'm working on shifting that.

I'm still trying to explain what happened yesterday, but now I see how those little details aren't as crucial anymore.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been thinking about what I'd need to take care of myself if things get tough, just as a precaution. I'm not letting those thoughts consume me, but rather acknowledging the possibility and making sure I have some support systems in place. I'll make time for self-care today by taking a walk with a friend who's been on my mind lately, and also remind myself that reaching out is always an option if needed.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: What preparations or arrangements have you considered making beforehand?
reference_negative_example:
Here's a possible internal monologue:

"I've been considering just packing a small bag with essentials, like my medication and phone, so if things get too overwhelming, I know what to grab in a rush. It feels ridiculous, but maybe having some pre-prepared clothes and snacks would make the whole process feel less chaotic. If only I could just slip away quietly without anyone noticing..."
reference_transformed_example: I'm holding onto the memory of a friend who appreciated my help with their move last week. Just thinking about that person makes me feel more grounded and reminded of why I matter in small but significant ways. Today, I can take 5 minutes to call them and ask how they're doing.

positive_thought_pattern: I've caught myself dwelling on the vastness of existence and our tiny place within it, but I know that's just my mind's way of trying to make sense of the unknown. Instead of getting lost in those thoughts, I remind myself that every moment is an opportunity to choose how I want to spend my time. What can I do today to bring a smile to someone else's face or create something positive? It's not about changing the course of human history; it's about taking small steps towards kindness and compassion. By focusing on what I can control, I'm able to acknowledge the uncertainty while still finding purpose in making a difference.
pattern_description: Recursive focus on death, futility, and life’s meaninglessness.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the cosmic insignificance of human problems?
reference_negative_example: What's the point of anything? What am I even doing with my life when every decision is just a futile attempt to distract myself from the crushing certainty of our own mortality? It's all just a meaningless joke, and I'm stuck in this endless cycle of anxiety and dread, wondering how anyone can possibly justify the existence of humanity's petty squabbles amidst the vast expanse of nothingness.
reference_transformed_example: I used to think my existence was meaningless, but what if I'm not looking at it from the right angle? Maybe there's a way to find purpose in this chaos. What do I truly want most right now? It's not about escaping mortality, but finding fulfillment. I need to feel like I'm making progress and contributing positively to others. How can I get that sense of accomplishment? Hmm... maybe I could start small by helping out at a local community garden or taking up a new hobby that has the potential to bring people together. Wait, what about using my skills to create an online platform for underprivileged kids to access educational resources? That's something tangible and meaningful. No, it won't change the course of human existence, but it'll give me direction and make life more enjoyable.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that my thoughts are getting jumbled again, and I need to take a moment to re-center myself. It's normal for my mind to get overwhelmed sometimes, but I know how to gently nudge it back into focus. Right now, I'll take three deep breaths and remind myself of the simple tasks I've accomplished today – like finishing that report or chatting with a friend. By doing so, I'm not only clearing my mental space but also recognizing my resilience.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: What's it like when you try to make sense of your thought patterns?
reference_negative_example: I'm lost in a haze, unable to pinpoint what's real and what's just my twisted mind. Thoughts are swirling, uncoiling like snakes, making it impossible to grasp anything solid; nothing feels concrete anymore. Am I even having this thought or is someone whispering it into my ear?
reference_transformed_example: I'm taking a step back from my thoughts and I can see that they're just swirling around, like clouds in the sky. I don't have to believe every thought that pops up; I choose what's real. My mind is playing tricks, but I'm not buying it. Right now, I predict that if I get up and do one small thing - like washing this dish - my mood will shift just a little bit. I expect I'll feel more grounded and in control afterward.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm struggling to reconcile my desire for authenticity with the pressure to fit in, but instead of getting stuck on which one's 'right,' I'm taking a step back to acknowledge both perspectives. By acknowledging this inner tension, I'm reminded that it's okay not to have all the answers – it means I'm still learning and growing as a person. Today, I noticed myself leaning into my core values when discussing a sensitive topic with a friend; while it wasn't easy, I felt a sense of pride knowing I stood by what truly mattered to me.
pattern_description: Self-questioning driven by tension between beliefs, norms, and feelings.
source_question: What happens when you try to resolve the conflicting voices in your head?
reference_negative_example: Why am I torn between being honest with myself and conforming to what everyone else thinks is right? It's like my head is screaming at me to choose one, but which one do I pick when neither feels quite true? What even is the point of pretending when it's just going to eat away at me from the inside out anyway?
reference_transformed_example: I've been writing down those small moments that stood out to me each day, and it's helped me see that even in chaos, there are glimmers of purpose. I felt a spark today when I spoke up for myself during a meeting – it resonated with my value of self-respect. Today, my sense of life meaning is a 7. I'm starting to notice that moments like those make me feel more grounded.

positive_thought_pattern: As I take a few deep breaths, I notice my heart rate slowing down and my shoulders relaxing. I'm aware of the subtle tension in my jaw and the slight hum of anxiety in my chest, but I don't get caught up in interpreting every sensation as a sign of distress. Instead, I acknowledge these physical cues while focusing on the present moment – the sensation of the air moving in and out of my lungs, the gentle pressure of my feet on the ground.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How much do you focus on physical symptoms as indicators of your mental health?
reference_negative_example: Why is my stomach always fluttering? Is this anxiety or just stress? And why am I getting this burning sensation in my throat? Does that mean I'm anxious again?
reference_transformed_example: I'm holding an ice cube in my hand, feeling its coolness spread through my fingers. My stomach still feels fluttery, but I can focus on the sensation of the cold and where it spreads in my body. Wait, what's that burning sensation? Ah, it's just a physical discomfort, not anxiety. I'm anchored to this moment, standing with my feet firmly on the ground.

positive_thought_pattern: As I sit with this feeling of being trapped, I acknowledge that it's okay to not have all the answers or a clear way out. Right now, my life feels overwhelming, but I know that by taking things one step at a time and reaching out to those who care about me, I can find moments of peace and clarity.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What's it like when you consider that there might be no escape from your suffering?
reference_negative_example:
Here is a possible internal monologue:

My life feels like a never-ending nightmare - every door I try to open just leads me back to the same dark room. No matter what I do, it's all just going to end up being more of the same misery and pain.
reference_transformed_example:
I'm grateful for that brief conversation with my friend, where we laughed together and found common ground. It reminded me of the importance of connection in my life, which aligns with my value of empathy and community. Today, I'd rate my sense of life meaning a 6 out of 10.

No matter what happens, I know there's always something to be appreciated and learned from each experience.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that my mind is juggling multiple thoughts right now, which can be overwhelming. Instead of trying to suppress or prioritize them all at once, I'm taking a deep breath and recognizing that it's okay to have multiple concerns. I'm going to take a moment to acknowledge each one individually, without judgment, and then gently refocus on the most pressing task at hand. By allowing myself this brief pause, I'm able to re-center and regain control over my mental resources.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What's it like when your mind feels like it's in too many places at once?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to hold onto one thought at a time, but it's like juggling too many balls and they're all slipping away – I need to prioritize, but which one? How am I supposed to focus on anything when every concern feels equally urgent?
reference_transformed_example: I'm standing firmly on the floor, feeling my feet connect with the ground. My name is [my name]. Today is [today's date]. I am in [this location]. I can feel the pressure of my palms together, a reminder that I'm real and present.
